_header: As the philosopher in meters doth write
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 212; attributed to George Ripley, with Epistle (in Ashmole (1652)
XAshmole, Elias. Theatrum Chemicum Britannicum. London: J. Grimond, 1652, 109-11) dedicating 975 to Edward IV [Singer (1928)
XSinger, Dorothea Waley. Catalogue of Latin and Vernacular Alchemical Manuscripts. 3 vols. Brussels: Lamertin, 1928-31, 810A].
Subjects: alchemy; Edward IV, work dedicated to
Bibliographic Ghosts: Oxford, Corpus Christi College 172, ff. 39v-43: epilogue to 975
_description: An alchemical poem on the red, black and white stones — in 8-line stanzas

BodAsh759.First Lines:
As the philosopher in metheours doith writeThat the liknesse of
                    bodies metalline be not transmutable…
BodAsh759.Last Lines:
…Thus shall ye haue bothe gret elixer and aurum potabileBy the
                    grace of God to whom be laude and joy eternally
BodAsh759.Note:
168 lines; the rest of the text on f. 105v has been
                    erased.

BodAsh1442.First Lines:
Take maydens vrine yonge of AgeAshen burnte bothe salte &
                    lyme…
BodAsh1442.Last Lines:
…And if I had more tyme & spacebetter to saye God sende me
                    grace
BodAsh1442.Note: 124 lines; written two lines of verse per line in MS.

BLSl3667.Editions:
Ashmole,  Elias. 
             Theatrum Chemicum Britannicum.
         London: J. Grimond, 1652: 111-16.
